title-group.article-title: Metastatic Mammary Carcinoma With DCIS-Like Morphology
title-group.subtitle: A Report of Two Cases

author-notes.corresp: John Coyne, Royal Liverpool Hospital, Prescott Street, Liverpool L7 8XP, UK Email: johnnycoyne@doctors.org.uk

abstract.p: Two cases of breast carcinoma with lymph node metastases are presented. In each case the metastases demonstrated the unusual phenomenon of resembling either cribriform or comedo DCIS. Furthermore both cases had the additional rare feature of demonstrable lymphatic involvement by DCIS-like carcinoma.

body.p: Metastatic breast carcinoma in lymph nodes may mimic all the morphological forms of intraduct carcinoma.1-6 It was previously postulated that this phenomenon represented a reversal to a noninvasive phenotype called revertant ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS). Although this concept has largely been disproved by immunohistochemistry, an additional morphological feature is presented in this report, providing further confirmation that it is a morphological variant of invasive breast carcinoma.

sec.title: Case1
sec.p: A 42-year-old female presented with a lump in her breast. Microscopic examination showed invasive ductal carcinoma grade 2 and areas resembling high-grade cribriform and comedo DCIS. Six of 8 lymph nodes showed a mixture of invasive ductal carcinoma and metastatic carcinoma with DCIS-like features (Figure 1). In addition, a focus resembling high-grade comedo DCIS was present in an adjacent afferent lymphatic vessel (Figure 2). Immunohistochemistry on the primary breast carcinoma displayed positive staining for myoepithelial cells around most but not all foci of DCIS with SMA and calponin but only focal positivity with p63. CD10 and cytokeratin 14 were nonreactive. All markers were negative in the lymph node metastases.

caption.p: Afferent vessel (adjacent to involved lymph node depicted in Figure 1) containing DCIS-like mammary carcinoma

sec.title: Case 2
sec.p: A 60-year-old female presented with a breast lump. Microscopic examination showed an infiltrating ductal carcinoma grade 1, which in places was cribriform in appearance and with interspersed foci of low-grade cribriform DCIS. Several foci of intravascular-lymphatic permeation by cribriform carcinoma were also present (Figure 3). Four of 6 lymph nodes showed a mixture of grade 1 ductal carcinoma and cribriform carcinoma resembling DCIS (Figure 4). Immunohistochemistry showed positively staining myoepithelial cells with SMA, calponin, and p63 around most of the foci of DCIS in the breast carcinoma. A few foci showed absent, partial, or attenuated reactivity. CD10 and cytokeratin 14 were negative. The lymph nodes were negative for all markers.

caption.p: Lymph node replaced by metastatic mammary carcinoma resembling cribriform DCIS
Invasive breast carcinoma with foci of vascular invasion resembling cribriform DCIS

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: In 1980, Cowen described an intraduct pattern of metastatic breast carcinoma in a lymph node metastasis; similar foci were present in the primary breast carcinoma.1 Cowen suggested that the presence of a basement membrane was not proof that they were not invasive carcinoma and that the appearances merely represented a morphological pattern of invasive cancer. In 1984, Cowen and Bates published a study on the significance of an intraduct appearance in breast cancer.2 They reported that, of the metastases showing an intraduct pattern, 43% had both an “intraduct” and invasive carcinoma in the primary breast tumor, whereas 37% showed only an invasive pattern. In 1997, Barsky et al, in a study of 200 cases of metastatic breast carcinoma, cited an incidence of DCIS morphology in the lymph node metastases of 21%.4 In addition, Barsky et al described complete morphological concordance between the primary and the lymph node metastases and described consistently a surrounding basement membrane but no myoepithelial cells with immunohistochemistry.4 Barsky et al concluded that this appearance represented a reversion to a noninvasive morphological phenotype.4 However, Lee et al in 1995 reported a case of metastatic breast carcinoma that had the appearance of micropapillary ductal carcinoma in situ.3 These areas, in both the primary tumor and in the metastasis, had a surrounding basement membrane but no myoepithelial cells with immunohistochemical examination. Furthermore, Kordek later described 2 cases of such metastatic breast carcinomas.5 The first case was an infiltrating ductal carcinoma without an intraductal component and with a metastasis resembling micropapillary intraductal carcinoma. The second case was an invasive ductal carcinoma with a component resembling DCIS of comedo type; 2 lymph node metastases resembled comedo DCIS. In contrast to the observations of Barsky et al, among whose cases were found no DCIS-like structures with basement membranes lacking myoepithelial cells, Kordek found an absence of myoepithelial cells in both the metastatic DCIS-like foci and also surrounding the comedo intraductal-like component in the primary carcinoma of case 2. In addition, Kordek cited an incidence of DCIS-like metastases of approximately 1.5%. With regard to the 2 cases reported herein, myoepithelial cells were present around some but not all the DCIS-like areas in the primary tumors and absent around the metastatic DCIS-like foci. This is in agreement with Kordek who interprets both the metastatic and in situ–like lesions as morphological forms of invasive carcinoma. Moreover, these 2 cases reported clearly demonstrate this morphologically invasive pattern metastasizing in flagranti as in situ patterns and confirming the original observations of Dr Cowen.1
